title: How to make my 9 yr old son to love reading books - Quora

response.answer_text: Firstly it is a great idea that you want to imbibe reading habit in a 6 year old. Afterall it is the small droplets that make the large ocean. At this young age one of the first things that you need to do is make him feel that as a parent you are into reading too. This might seem a slightly unconventional idea but children learn a lot by immitation. If the child sees you reading and surrounding yourself by books, he will develop a natural tendency to do the same by himself. Most parents do not read nowadays and are hooked on to their phones. There is no point in blaming your child for something you do yourself. Once he grows an inclination to look at books, try to bring in illustrative books. Books with colourful illustrations can catch a child’s attention easily. Once he is attracted to the books he will develop a subtle habit of reading. You can start with books having very short stories and anecdotes and read them to him. Ask him to read after you and then by himself. Once he gets into this practice he will get the essence of reading. If possible take him to book fairs or shops where he can look at a variety of books and even choose. You also need to keep a watch on his screen time, so that he spends less time looking at a screen. This time can be valuably devoted to outdoor games and reading books, a habit that would pay him well throughout his life.

Switch from YouTube Videos to AudiobooksYes, audiobooks count as reading—and they can help children do it better. Hearing someone reading a book confidently is a great way to experience fluency, which is the ability to read a text accurately, quickly, and with good expression. 2. Start With YOU! “Children take cues from adults”. When you grow up surrounded by junk food, you like junk food. When you grow up surrounded by books, you like books. Make sure they see you reading, and talk to them about the book. Try excitedly pointing out something that reminds you of the story, because you want them to see that books bring you joy and will bring them joy too. 3. Read the books and then watch the movie. Pick a classic that’s been turned into a movie—Bridge to Terabithia; The Lion, the Witch, and the Wardrobe; or Charlie and the Chocolate Factory—and read it together, a few chapters at a time. When you’re finished, host a family movie night to watch the film version. It’s a great way to motivate children to read. 4. Stash Books All Over “Surrounding kids with books at an early age gets them hooked,” says Alice Sterling Honig, Ph.D., a child development expert at Syracuse University, in New York. Just like you surround your kids with limitless toys, this time try replacing it with books. Give a book to keep him/her busy instead of handing a toy in their hand. Do not keep the books in the shelves, put it somewhere close to them, where they would most likely find it or stumble upon. 5. Read Aloud - even when they don't need it Reading aloud is both educational and social, so there are layers of value there. Plus, children learn to read best—and to love it most—when they hear countless stories over many years in a meaningful context. This also gives the reader a break. GuysRead.com, specifically for boys, and ReadingRockets.org are excellent sites for book ideas broken down by age and interests. I hope this answers helps you imbibe a reading habit into your child.

A2A, for which, Thanks. My answer is not original. Read to them. Read with them. Don’t force them always to read at the very highest level of which they are capable. I am not saying that children should never stretch while they are reading, but reading things that are easy for them but still interesting to them will do marvels for their confidence. I had two children who struggled to learn to read. We would read every other paragraph, or sometimes they would read one sentence and I would read the rest of the paragraph. Keep it as much fun as possible. Reading with a child tucked under your arm is wonderful. Read things with them that are at their level. Read things to them that they can understand but might have difficulty reading. Ask them what they are enjoying. Try to figure out what kind of books they like. Go to the library with them and let them choose the books that they want to read. If they are having a lot of difficulty with the reading, try to figure out what the problem is. Do they really solidly know the letters? Can they see clearly? Do they report that the letters seem to move on the page? But if the difficulty is no interest, the best thing is doing it with them.

Read to them. when my son started school he was not interested in the books he was asked to read, but he loved to hear ‘Green Eggs and Ham’, by Dr Seuss, so much so that we read it so often, with him on my knee, watching my finger run under the words that he learnt to read that way. I knew, when he was six and he could get from the beginning to the end he could read, a six year old can’t memorise that much. Find a book they like, read it to them, show them the words as you read, and even if you read the same book over and over again, do it. Also, ask them questions about it - ‘What happens next?’, ‘Why do you think he did that?’ And don’t worry if you think the book is way above their ability level, it’s their interest you want.

I have answered several questions on this topic and so have many other people so I suggest you search Quora for all those answers about children and reading. My advice is READ TO YOUR CHILD. Don’t wait until they are that age, start earlier because around the age of 7 - 9 many kids, especially boys, suddenly find physical activities are a bit more exciting than reading books. But if enjoyment for reading has been given to them earlier, they will return to it after the games are over. LIMIT their time on devices like ipad and phones. LIMIT their TV and movie watching and computer gameing. LET YOUR CHILDREN SEE YOU READING. That is very important. And READ TO YOUR CHILD.

Kids learn by example. So the best way is for you to also develop (if not already) a reading habit. That way, your enthusiasm will rub off on your children. It helps a lot too if you read to them, since birth if possible. They will associate books with fun bonding time with their parent, and grow used to having books around them. My grandparents and parents were/are avid readers, there always were books in every room of the house. I learned to read by kindergarten. By 7–9 I was reading Sherlock Holmes and other classics as well as children’s books by Enid Blyton and fairy tales.

Well, it’s a bit of a late start at 9, but better late than never! I would start reading to them every night before bed. My children and I read at bedtime every night, but now my 7 year old reads the books to me and his brother. He’s still choppy and lacks proper inflection sometimes, but I’m there to help him. Don’t make him read yet, read to him to gather his interest, then transition to him reading. Go to the library and pick out new books together. Let him get books he wants or thinks might be interesting. Above all else, don’t force him to read, this will most likely have the opposite effect than what you want.

Give him something that will connect with his personality and character. Give him something that he will like to read. The thing that schools do is give kids something like The Odyssey or To Kill A Mockingbird and that’s not right because if you want someone to love reading, give them something they love and that should be done with children at a very young age. If you teach a fish to climb a tree it will spend its whole life believing it is stupid. If you teach a fish to swim, it will thrive.

I don’t have children of my own but I hated reading when I was that age range . I actually like reading now. I think the best way to get them interested is to let them read books like the chose your own adventure series and books that they can comprehend well. When they are this age don’t force them to read classical novels; they can read them later let them read what they want within reason. Let them still read picture books if they like them, eventually they will read regular books.

Make books a part of your life. Go to the library if possible. I don’t know if this is happening in the Covid world. Regardless books are the key. Find books especially that are nonfiction! Boys in particular love to read about real things! What is your child interested in? That’s where you start! And 9 year olds ARE NOT too old for read-alouds! Read a chapter or a few pages of a book that you both enjoy—-a bedtime story is not out of the question. A book at bedtime is a wonderful way to end the day. Not knowing your child except by age, think about the Harry Potter series or some other series. Kids like what’s familiar and a series would fit the bill. Just remember that you need to be a part of this! Your involvement is key. This might actually be a place where living in a Covid world could pay exceptional dividends!

Read. Read, yourself. Share your enjoyment of reading—Oh hey: I just read this wonderful thing today..! Read to him—read stuff he picks out, you pick out, stuff ‘over his head,’ stuff more intellectually age-appropriate (whatever that means to you and him). Ask a librarian for recommendations. Follow your son’s interests, e.g., if he’s into space, find space books, if he’s into dinosaurs, or trucks, or ballet, find books, magazines, comics featuring these things. Hope this helps.

I don't have any original ideas about this except to say how my own children got interested in reading. There were bedtime stories, visits to the library, lots of books in the house. They also watched me reading quite a lot. They never got directly encouraged to read, but were left to follow their own inclination as regards books. They grew up choosing their own reading material. No doubt they received guidance at school though.

Read to him, or use audio books while he pages through the hard copy version. Make sure there is a wide variety of reading material around, of every kind—even stuff like cereal boxes or other labels—and be sure he sees you reading them, for both entertainment and information.

There are good books for nine year olds. I suggest first start with comics. In India, Amar Chitra Katha are worth reading. Other comics are Asterix which deals with the period of Julius Caesar and Tintin which is set in more modern times. Both are outright funny. Later on he can graduate to heavier books but these books will give him a love for reading.

If you are a comfortable aloud reader - read aloud to him from high interest books. What are his interests? Matt Christopher wrote a series of sports book for young boys. Of course let him see you reading and talk about the books you read and why you're enjoying the book. If you're not a comfortable aloud reader - get recorded books and listen to them together - it's not unusual for a six year old to not like reading. Their reading skills are not at the level yet that allows them read books with intriguing plots. Try the Goosebumps series - for high interest books.
Not forcing them to read. Put them in a room full of books. Show them how reading a book works. Then leave them. If they are bored, they will read eventually.
